parts.text: What is the cost ratio of GPT-4 to GPT-3.5 Turbo?
The cost ratio is roughly 50:1, making GPT-3.5-Turbo about 50 times cheaper to use than GPT-4.
How much GPU memory is typically required for a 7 billion parameter model for serving?
A 7 billion parameter model typically requires about 14GB of GPU memory for serving.
What can save you 40-90% in token costs when asking an LLM for responses?
Appending “Be Concise” to your prompt can save 40-90% in token costs.
What is the average tokens per word in an LLM?
On average, there are 1.3 tokens per word in an LLM.
What is the memory capacity of an A100 GPU?
The memory capacity of an A100 GPU is either 40GB or 80GB.
What is the typical GPU memory requirement for an embedding model?
The typical GPU memory requirement for an embedding model is about 1GB.
What is the cost to train a 13-billion parameter model on 1.4 trillion tokens?
The cost is approximately $1 million.
How much cheaper is it to use a self-hosted base model versus a fine-tuned one?
When self-hosting, the cost of serving a base model is about the same as a fine-tuned one.
What is the cost ratio of OpenAI embedding to self-hosted embedding?
The cost ratio is approximately 10:1, making self-hosting 10 times cheaper.
How much UI throughput improvement can batching LLM requests achieve?
Batching LLM requests can achieve more than 10x throughput improvement.
What problem do Transformers encounter with long sequences?
The time and memory complexity of self-attention are quadratic in sequence length, making Transformers slow and memory-hungry on long sequences.
What principle is argued to be missing in attention algorithms, according to the paper?
The paper argues that attention algorithms lack IO-awareness, which involves accounting for reads and writes between levels of GPU memory.
What is FlashAttention?
FlashAttention is an IO-aware exact attention algorithm that uses tiling to reduce the number of memory reads/writes between GPU high bandwidth memory (HBM) and GPU on-chip SRAM.
How does FlashAttention improve training speed compared to baselines?
FlashAttention trains Transformers faster than existing baselines, achieving a 15% end-to-end wall-clock speedup on BERT-large, a 3x speedup on GPT-2, and a 2.4x speedup on long-range arena.
What is the impact of FlashAttention on Transformer model quality?
FlashAttention enables longer context in Transformers, yielding higher quality models with better perplexity on GPT-2 and significant improvement on long-document classification tasks.
What new capabilities does FlashAttention enable in Transformers?
FlashAttention enables Transformers to achieve better-than-chance performance on the Path-X challenge and Path-256, handling sequence lengths of up to 64K.
Who are the authors of the paper titled FlashAttention: Fast and Memory-Efficient Exact Attention with IO-Awareness?
The authors are Tri Dao, Daniel Y. Fu, Stefano Ermon, Atri Rudra, and Christopher Ré.
When was the paper on FlashAttention first submitted?
It was first submitted on May 27, 2022.
What is one key technology FlashAttention uses to improve efficiency?
FlashAttention uses tiling to reduce the number of memory reads/writes.
How is the DOI for the paper on FlashAttention cited?
The paper can be cited using the DOI https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2205.14135.
What is vLLM?
vLLM is a fast and easy-to-use library for LLM inference and serving.
What accelerates vLLM serving throughput?
Efficient management of attention key and value memory with PagedAttention accelerates vLLM serving throughput.
How can one install vLLM?
vLLM can be installed with the command: pip install vllm.
Which GPUs and CPUs does vLLM support?
vLLM supports NVIDIA GPUs, AMD CPUs and GPUs, Intel CPUs and GPUs, PowerPC CPUs, TPU, and AWS Neuron.
Who provides support for the open-source development of vLLM?
Organizations like a16z, AMD, AWS, Dropbox, Google Cloud, NVIDIA, and several others provide support for the development of vLLM.
What type of API server does vLLM provide?
vLLM provides an OpenAI-compatible API server.
What are some of the quantization methods supported by vLLM?
vLLM supports quantizations such as GPTQ, AWQ, INT4, INT8, and FP8.
How does vLLM integrate with existing models?
vLLM seamlessly integrates with popular Hugging Face models.
What type of parallelism does vLLM support?
vLLM supports both tensor parallelism and pipeline parallelism for distributed inference.
How does vLLM handle batching of requests?
vLLM handles batching of requests using continuous batching of incoming requests.
What is vLLM?
vLLM is an open-source library for fast LLM inference and serving that utilizes the PagedAttention algorithm to manage attention keys and values efficiently.
What is PagedAttention?

PagedAttention is an attention algorithm inspired by virtual memory and paging in operating systems, allowing efficient management of attention keys and values by storing them in non-contiguous memory spaces.
How does vLLM compare to HuggingFace Transformers in terms of throughput?
vLLM delivers up to 24x higher throughput than HuggingFace Transformers without requiring model architecture changes.
What are the two GPU settings used for evaluating vLLM performance?
The two GPU settings are LLaMA-7B on an NVIDIA A10G GPU and LLaMA-13B on an NVIDIA A100 GPU (40GB).
How does PagedAttention manage memory differently than traditional attention algorithms?
PagedAttention partitions the KV cache into blocks and allows keys and values to be stored in non-contiguous memory spaces, reducing memory waste and enabling efficient memory sharing.
What improvement in throughput can PagedAttention achieve during parallel sampling?
PagedAttention can reduce memory usage by up to 55% and improve throughput by up to 2.2x during parallel sampling.
How has the integration of vLLM improved LMSYS’s service in Chatbot Arena?
Integration of vLLM in FastChat allowed LMSYS to handle up to 30x more throughput than the initial HF backend and reduce GPU usage by 50%.
What are some of the models supported by vLLM?
Some of the models supported by vLLM include Vicuna, Koala, LLaMA, Databricks Dolly, LAION’s OpenAssistant, and Stability AI’s stableLM.
How can you install vLLM?
vLLM can be installed using the command: pip install vllm.
What command is used to query the vLLM server in an OpenAI API-compatible way?

The command to query the vLLM server is: curl http://localhost:8000/v1/completions -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{ "model": "lmsys/vicuna-7b-v1.3", "prompt": "San Francisco is a", "max_tokens": 7, "temperature": 0 }'
What problem does PagedAttention aim to address in large language model serving?

PagedAttention addresses the issue of inefficient key-value cache (KV cache) memory management, which leads to significant memory waste due to fragmentation and redundant duplication, limiting batch size during high throughput serving of large language models.
What classical techniques inspire the PagedAttention algorithm?
The PagedAttention algorithm is inspired by the classical virtual memory and paging techniques in operating systems.
What is vLLM and what does it achieve?

vLLM is a large language model (LLM) serving system built on top of the PagedAttention algorithm, achieving near-zero waste in KV cache memory and flexible sharing of KV cache within and across requests to reduce memory usage.
How does vLLM improve the throughput of popular LLMs compared to state-of-the-art systems?
vLLM improves the throughput of popular large language models by 2-4 times with the same level of latency when compared to state-of-the-art systems like FasterTransformer and Orca.
What factors make the improvement of vLLM more pronounced?
The improvement of vLLM is more pronounced with longer sequences, larger models, and more complex decoding algorithms.
Where is the source code of vLLM publicly available?
The source code of vLLM is publicly available at the provided URL link in the paper.
When was the paper submitted to arXiv?
The paper was submitted to arXiv on 12 September 2023.
What subjects does this paper fall under?
The paper falls under the subjects of Machine Learning (cs.LG) and Distributed, Parallel, and Cluster Computing (cs.DC).
What event is the paper associated with?
The paper is associated with SOSP 2023.
Who is the first listed author of the paper?
The first listed author of the paper is Woosuk Kwon.
What does RLHF stand for?
RLHF stands for Reinforcement Learning with Human Feedback.
What is the key advantage of using the trl library for fine-tuning?
The trl library makes the RL step much easier and more flexible, allowing anyone to fine-tune their LM using RL on their custom dataset and training setup.
What is the benefit of loading a model in 8-bit precision?
Loading a model in 8-bit precision can save up to 4x memory compared to a full precision model.
What is the purpose of PEFT?
The purpose of PEFT is to support the creation and fine-tuning of adapter layers on LLMs, enabling memory-efficient model training.
What is PPO and how is it used in the context of TRL?
PPO, or Proximal Policy Optimization, is a popular deep RL algorithm that can be run in a distributed manner or on a single device using trl.
How can Low-Rank Adapters benefit the fine-tuning of large language models?
Low-Rank Adapters allow fine-tuning with far less GPU memory by freezing pretrained weights and creating low-rank versions of query and value layers attention matrices with fewer parameters.
What challenges are associated with training language models at scale?
Challenges include fitting the model and optimizer states on available GPU devices, managing GPU memory per parameter, and adopting parallelism strategies like Pipeline, Tensor, and Data Parallelism.
What is the main downside of using Low-Rank Adapters?
The forward and backward pass is approximately twice as slow due to additional matrix multiplications in the adapter layers.
Why is the choice of the base LLM crucial when using RLHF?

The choice of the base LLM is crucial because it significantly affects the model’s performance, and instruction finetuned LLMs like BLOOMZ, Flan-T5, Flan-UL2, and OPT-IML are considered "best" for many tasks.
What is the main goal when fine-tuning a LLM with RL using the trl library?
The main goal is to make fine-tuning more accessible, enabling anyone to generate positive outputs like movie reviews in a memory-constrained setting.
What are the two Linux kernel features that allow process isolation in containers?
The two Linux kernel features are namespaces and cgroups.
What command can be used to create a new PID namespace and run bash in it?
The command is 'sudo unshare --fork --pid --mount-proc bash'.
What does cgroups allow you to do in the context of containers?
Cgroups allow you to set resource limits, such as memory and CPU usage, for processes.
What command can you use to enter the namespace of another running program?
The command is 'nsenter'.
How does seccomp-bpf contribute to container security?
Seccomp-bpf allows you to filter and restrict which system calls a process can run.
What is Docker primarily built on, in terms of Linux kernel features?
Docker is built on Linux kernel primitives like namespaces and cgroups.
How would you limit a program's memory to 10 megabytes using cgroups?
You can limit memory by setting '10000000' in '/sys/fs/cgroup/memory/mycoolgroup/memory.limit_in_bytes'.
What does the 'unshare' command do in relation to Linux namespaces?
The 'unshare' command creates a new namespace by invoking the 'unshare' system call.
What is the purpose of the 'cgexec' command?
The 'cgexec' command runs a program in a specified cgroup.
What error might you encounter when compiling a Rust program in a memory-limited cgroup?
The error encountered might be 'Cannot allocate memory (os error 12)'.
What is Kubernetes also known as?
Kubernetes is also known as K8s.
What type of system is Kubernetes?
Kubernetes is an open source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.
What type of workloads can Kubernetes scale to support?
Kubernetes can scale to support production workloads at Google, designed on the same principles that allow Google to run billions of containers a week.
How does Kubernetes ensure application health during updates?

Kubernetes progressively rolls out changes to your application or its configuration, while monitoring application health to ensure it doesn't kill all your instances at the same time. If something goes wrong, Kubernetes will rollback the change for you.
What feature of Kubernetes allows you to run K8s anywhere?
Kubernetes being open source gives you the freedom to take advantage of on-premises, hybrid, or public cloud infrastructure.
Which Kubernetes feature offers service discovery and load balancing?
Kubernetes provides Pods their own IP addresses and a single DNS name for a set of Pods, and can load-balance across them.
What is the self-healing ability of Kubernetes?
Kubernetes restarts containers that fail, replaces and reschedules containers when nodes die, and kills containers that don't respond to your user-defined health check.
Which Kubernetes feature allows for horizontal scaling?
Kubernetes allows for horizontal scaling up and down with a simple command, with a UI, or automatically based on CPU usage.
What languages are available for Kubernetes documentation?
The Kubernetes documentation is available in languages including English, বাংলা (Bengali), 中文 (Chinese), Français (French), Deutsch (German), हिन्दी (Hindi), and more.
When does KubeCon + CloudNativeCon India take place in 2024?
KubeCon + CloudNativeCon India takes place on December 11-12, 2024.
What is the Alibaba Cloud service that integrates virtualization, storage, networking, and security capabilities?
Alibaba Cloud Container Service for Kubernetes (ACK)
Which Alibaba Cloud product supports multi-cluster management and offers optimized OS images for Kubernetes containers?
ACK Self-Managed Kubernetes
Which feature of Alibaba Cloud Container Service for Kubernetes allows for the creation and management of worker nodes while master nodes are managed by ACK?
Managed Kubernetes
What type of Alibaba Cloud Kubernetes cluster allows you to perform more fine-grained control on infrastructure?
Dedicated Kubernetes
What Alibaba Cloud solution is available for batch tasks and CI/CD tests without the need to manage any nodes?
Container Service for Kubernetes Serverless
Which best practice involves using Kompose and Helm for deploying Spring Cloud applications in an ACK Cluster?
Deploying a Spring Cloud Application in an ACK Cluster
What is Name a customer that utilized Alibaba Cloud to manage software applications in a flexible, reliable, and cost-effective manner.?
RedMart
What is the advantage of using the auto-scaling feature of ACK mentioned by Perfect Diary?
Reduction in server costs by more than 50%
What feature of ACK supports communication between containers on different hosts?
Networking with VPC support for high-performance networks
What type of consultation does Alibaba Cloud offer for personal advice on cloud solutions?
1 on 1 Presale Consultation
What is Amazon EKS?
Amazon EKS (Elastic Kubernetes Service) is a fully managed Kubernetes service that enables users to run Kubernetes seamlessly in both AWS Cloud and on-premises data centers.
What are some benefits of using Amazon EKS?
Amazon EKS accelerates time to production, unifies Kubernetes management across environments, improves performance, availability, and resiliency, and enhances system security.
How does Amazon EKS streamline Kubernetes operations?
Amazon EKS streamlines Kubernetes operations by automating cluster infrastructure management with just one click.
Can Kubernetes be run in different environments using Amazon EKS?
Yes, Amazon EKS allows you to unify Kubernetes management across cloud, on-premises, and edge locations, giving you flexibility to run your workloads anywhere.
How does Amazon EKS enhance system security?
Amazon EKS enhances system security by applying operating system patches and updates, using ephemeral compute to limit security risks, and leveraging native integrations with AWS security services.
What features does Amazon EKS offer for running Kubernetes in on-premises environments?

Amazon EKS allows the same clusters, features, and tools to be used for running Kubernetes in on-premises environments with AWS Outposts or using EKS Anywhere for self-contained air-gapped environments.
Why would one use Amazon EKS for deploying data solutions?
Amazon EKS can be used to deploy scalable, high-performing, and cost-efficient data platforms with AWS-managed services or open source tools.
What is a use case of deploying highly-performant large language models (LLMs) with Amazon EKS?
Amazon EKS can be used to deploy secure, scalable, and high-performing LLMs to drive generative AI applications for both training and inference, leveraging GPU instances in AWS infrastructure.
How can Amazon EKS help in building and running web applications?

Amazon EKS enables the creation of web applications that automatically scale up and down and run in a highly available configuration across multiple Availability Zones (AZs) with integrated networking and security.
What languages is the AWS website available in?
The AWS website is available in languages such as English, Español, Français, Italiano, Deutsch, 中文 (简体), 中文 (繁體), 日本語, 한국어, and more.
What is Fabric for Deep Learning (FfDL)?
FfDL is a Deep Learning Platform offering TensorFlow, Caffe, PyTorch etc. as a Service on Kubernetes.
What is the minimum capacity requirement for FfDL?
The minimum capacity requirement for FfDL is 4GB Memory and 3 CPUs.
Which companies or industries can benefit from using GitHub solutions?
Enterprises, small and medium teams, startups, healthcare, financial services, manufacturing, and government industries.
What is the purpose of the Adversarial Robustness Toolbox in FfDL?
To find vulnerabilities in deep learning models.
What command is used to initialize tiller in Kubernetes?
The command used is "helm init".
What interface is used to configure Object Storage in FfDL?
The S3 CLI (command-line interface) is used to configure Object Storage.
Which IBM service can be used for further training and serving models trained on FfDL?
Watson Studio Deep Learning service can be used for further training and serving models.
What are some key topics related to FfDL according to the repository?

Python, machine-learning, deep-neural-networks, Caffe, AI, deep-learning, Jupyter, storage, Watson, TensorFlow, model, Keras, ML, Kubernetes-cluster, PyTorch, artificial-intelligence, deeplearning, and IBM-research-AI.
What kind of dashboard does FfDL offer for monitoring?
FfDL offers a simple Grafana monitoring dashboard.
What license is FfDL released under?
FfDL is released under the Apache-2.0 license.
What does IBM Watson Studio empower data scientists, developers, and analysts to do?
To build, run and manage AI models, and optimize decisions anywhere on IBM Cloud Pak for Data.
What open source frameworks does IBM Watson Studio support?
IBM Watson Studio supports open source frameworks like PyTorch, TensorFlow, and scikit-learn.
What can users do with the Watson Natural Language Processing Premium Environment?
Users can access pre-trained, high-quality text analysis models in over 20 languages.
What automated features does AutoAI provide?
AutoAI provides automated data preparation, model development, feature engineering, and hyperparameter optimization.
What is the purpose of AI governance in IBM Watson Studio?
AI governance provides automated tools and processes to direct, manage, and monitor AI workflows, ensuring transparent and explainable analytic results.
What is the new enterprise studio launched by IBM?
IBM launched watsonx.ai, an enterprise studio that combines traditional machine learning with new generative AI capabilities powered by foundation models.
What does decision optimization in Watson Studio enable?
Decision optimization streamlines the selection and deployment of optimization models and enables the creation of dashboards to share results and enhance collaboration.
How does visual modeling benefit users in Watson Studio?
Visual modeling allows users to combine visual data science with open source libraries and notebook-based interfaces on a unified data and AI platform.
How does IBM Watson Studio support multicloud architecture?
By uniting teams, automating AI lifecycles, and speeding time to value on an open multicloud architecture.
What savings can be achieved with explainable AI according to Forrester?
Explainable AI can reduce model monitoring efforts by 35% to 50% and increase model accuracy by 15% to 30%.
What is the purpose of Amazon SageMaker?
Amazon SageMaker is a unified platform for data, analytics, and AI, delivering an integrated experience for analytics and AI with unified access to all your data.
What features does Amazon SageMaker Unified Studio provide?
Amazon SageMaker Unified Studio provides an integrated experience to use all your data and tools for analytics and AI, including model development, data processing, and SQL analytics.
How does Amazon SageMaker promote enterprise security?

Amazon SageMaker ensures enterprise security with built-in governance throughout the entire data and AI lifecycle, allowing control of access to data, models, and development artifacts by the right user for the right purpose.
What are the benefits of using Amazon SageMaker Lakehouse?

Amazon SageMaker Lakehouse unifies data access across Amazon S3 data lakes, Amazon Redshift data warehouses, and third-party data sources, providing a single copy of analytics data with fine-grained permissions.
How does Amazon SageMaker accelerate AI development?

Amazon SageMaker accelerates AI development with a comprehensive set of AI tools, secure infrastructure, and the Amazon Q Developer, which helps discover data, train models, generate SQL queries, and create data pipelines.
How have companies like Roche benefited from using Amazon SageMaker?

Companies like Roche have enhanced data access and reduced data errors, with a 40% decrease in processing time and quicker analytics data write-back, empowering teams to focus on creating business value.
What languages are supported for AWS documentation?
AWS documentation is available in multiple languages including English, Español, Français, Deutsch, Italiano, Português, 日本語, and 中文.
What are some of the AI development capabilities in Amazon SageMaker?
Amazon SageMaker includes high-performance IDEs, distributed training, inference, AI ops, governance, observability, and the ability to rapidly create generative AI applications.
What is Amazon Q Developer?
Amazon Q Developer is a generative AI assistant for software development that aids in discovering data, building and training ML models, generating SQL queries, and creating data pipeline jobs.
What is the significance of Amazon SageMaker Catalog?
Amazon SageMaker Catalog is built on Amazon DataZone and helps securely discover, govern, and collaborate on data and AI with fine-grained access controls.
What is the SLA for Azure Machine Learning?
The SLA for Azure Machine Learning is 99.9 percent uptime.
What features does Azure Machine Learning offer for classification, regression, vision, and natural language processing?
Azure Machine Learning offers automated machine learning to rapidly create accurate machine learning models for classification, regression, vision, and natural language processing.
How does Azure ensure the security of its Machine Learning service?
Azure ensures security with built-in security and compliance, supported by an investment of $20 billion in cybersecurity and over 8,500 security and threat intelligence experts.
What is responsible AI in the context of Azure?
Responsible AI in Azure involves developing AI solutions with interpretability capabilities, assessing model fairness through disparity metrics, and mitigating unfairness.
How does Azure Machine Learning assist with model deployment?
Azure Machine Learning provides managed endpoints to operationalize model deployment and scoring, log metrics, and perform safe model rollouts.
What is Azure Machine Learning studio?
Azure Machine Learning studio is the top-level resource for developers and data scientists to build, train, and deploy machine learning models centrally.
Can you use Azure Machine Learning with no extra cost?
Yes, Azure Machine Learning can be used with no extra cost, but you will incur charges for the underlying compute resources during model training or inference.
How does Azure Machine Learning support collaborative model management?
Azure Machine Learning supports collaborative model management through its MLOps capabilities, which streamline model management and operations.
What kind of AI infrastructure does Azure Machine Learning use?
Azure Machine Learning uses purpose-built AI infrastructure that combines the latest GPUs and InfiniBand networking.
How are generative AI features in Azure Machine Learning different from the Azure OpenAI Service?
Azure Machine Learning supports language model fine-tuning and deployment, while Azure OpenAI Service provides pre-built language models for integration.
What is Vertex AI?
Vertex AI is a fully-managed, unified AI development platform for building and using generative AI, offering access to Vertex AI Studio, Agent Builder, and 160+ foundation models.
What are Gemini models?
Gemini models are Google’s most capable multimodal models, capable of understanding virtually any input, combining different types of information, and generating almost any output.
How does the Vertex AI Platform support MLOps?

Vertex AI Platform provides purpose-built MLOps tools for automating, standardizing, and managing ML projects using modular tools for evaluation, pipelines, model registry, feature store, and monitoring.
What is the purpose of the Vertex AI Agent Builder?
Vertex AI Agent Builder enables developers to easily build and deploy generative AI experiences, providing a no-code agent builder console along with powerful customization capabilities.
How many generative AI models and tools are available in Model Garden?
Model Garden in Vertex AI offers over 150+ generative AI models and tools, including first-party, third-party, and open models.
What is the starting price for hosting Texford Generative Models?
The starting price for text, chat, and code generation using generative models in Vertex AI is $0.0001 per 1,000 characters.
How does Vertex AI enable faster AI innovation?
Vertex AI enables faster innovation with enterprise-ready generative AI by providing several options for model training and deployment, including Gemini 1.5 Pro and Gemini 1.5 Flash.
What is the purpose of Vertex AI Studio?

Vertex AI Studio is a tool in Google Cloud console for rapidly prototyping and testing generative AI models, allowing users to design prompts, tune foundation models, and convert between speech and text.
What benefits does AutoML on Vertex AI provide?
Vertex AI’s AutoML allows for creating and training high-quality custom machine learning models with minimal effort and expertise, by automating tedious work like curating videos, images, and texts.
How can you access Gemini models in Vertex AI?
You can access Gemini models in Vertex AI via the Gemini API, and they are available for all customers with the ability to handle a variety of AI tasks.
What is Amazon SageMaker Training?
Amazon SageMaker Training is a fully managed machine learning (ML) service offered by SageMaker that helps you efficiently train a wide range of ML models at scale.
What are the three main use cases for training ML models within SageMaker AI?

The three main use cases are: 1) Develop a machine learning model in a low-code or no-code environment, 2) Use code to develop machine learning models with more flexibility and control, 3) Develop machine learning models at scale with maximum flexibility and control.
What is SageMaker JumpStart?
SageMaker JumpStart provides access to the SageMaker AI public model hub, allowing you to fine-tune, evaluate, and deploy foundation models within Amazon SageMaker Studio.
What feature of SageMaker AI helps optimize compute cost and efficiency for training instance provisioning?
Heterogeneous Cluster, Managed Spot instances, or Managed Warm Pools are features that help optimize compute cost and efficiency for training instance provisioning.
Which SageMaker AI feature allows for low/no-code model development?
Amazon SageMaker Canvas allows for low/no-code and UI-driven model development with quick experimentation with a training dataset.
How does SageMaker HyperPod facilitate massive ML workloads?

SageMaker HyperPod accelerates development of state-of-the-art foundation models by removing heavy-lifting in building and maintaining large compute clusters with GPUs like AWS Trainium or NVIDIA A100 and H100.
What is the purpose of SageMaker Hyperparameter Tuning?
SageMaker Hyperparameter Tuning helps define a set of hyperparameters for a model, launching many training jobs to find the best performing set of hyperparameters within given ranges.
What capability does SageMaker AI use for model hosting?
SageMaker AI uses Docker images to host the training and serving of all models.
What does distributed training with SageMaker AI enable?

Distributed training allows pre-training or fine-tuning foundation models built with frameworks like PyTorch while utilizing GPU instances efficiently using SageMaker AI libraries for communication operations and model parallelism.
What environment is recommended for maximal scalability and flexibility in model training on SageMaker?
SageMaker JupyterLab within Amazon SageMaker Studio is recommended for training models at scale with maximum flexibility and control.
What is the main issue causing delays in OpenAI's short-term plans?
OpenAI is extremely GPU-limited, which is delaying their short-term plans.
What are OpenAI's top priorities for 2023 according to their near-term roadmap?
Cheaper and faster GPT-4, longer context windows, finetuning API extensions, and a stateful API.
What does Sam Altman suggest about ChatGPT plugins in the API?
Sam Altman suggested that ChatGPT plugins probably will not be available in the API anytime soon because they don’t have PMF yet.
What commitment is required to access OpenAI's dedicated capacity offering?
Customers must be willing to commit to a $100k spend upfront to access OpenAI's dedicated capacity offering.
What is OpenAI's approach to competition with their customers?
OpenAI will avoid competing with their customers other than with ChatGPT and will not release more products beyond ChatGPT.
What does Sam Altman believe about open-sourcing GPT-3?
Sam Altman believes in the importance of open source and said that OpenAI was considering open-sourcing GPT-3.
What is the scaling hypothesis related to AGI development?

The scaling hypothesis is the idea that existing methods and scaling them up to larger models and bigger datasets may lead to building AGI, suggesting shorter timelines due to the continuing scalability of AI models.
What does "scaling laws still hold" imply for model performance?
It implies that making AI models larger will continue to yield performance gains, though at a slower rate of scaling.
What did Sam Altman identify as OpenAI's biggest customer complaint?
The biggest customer complaint was about the reliability and speed of the API due to GPU shortages.
What year was this article about OpenAI's plans published?
The article was published on May 29, 2023.
What generation of infrastructure for enterprise AI does the NVIDIA DGX Systems represent?
NVIDIA's latest generation
What processors are used in the Scalar Server by Lambda?
Dual Xeon or AMD EPYC processors
What is the GPU configuration of the Vector GPU Desktop by Lambda?
Configured with two NVIDIA RTX 4500 Ada or RTX 5000 Ada
How many customizable NVIDIA GPUs can the Vector Pro GPU Workstation by Lambda have?
Up to four
What is the price of the RTX 2080 Ti GPU?
By what factor does using FP16 training on the RTX 2080 Ti speed up ResNet-50 compared to FP32?
59% faster
On the RTX 2080 Ti, how much faster is FP16 training compared to FP32 on the AlexNet model?
38% faster
For multi-GPU training performance, how much faster is training with 4x RTX 2080 Ti GPUs than with 1x?
~3.3x faster
What is recommended for those new to machine learning or testing code, FP16 or FP32?
FP32
What are the three main hardware configurations mentioned for single and multi-GPU training in Lambda systems?
Lambda Quad, Lambda Blade, Lambda Hyperplane
What is model parallelism?
Model parallelism is a distributed training method in which the deep learning model is partitioned across multiple devices, within or across instances.
Why is model parallelism important for deep learning tasks?

Increasing the size of deep learning models yields better accuracy for complex tasks, but there is a limit to the maximum model size that can fit in a single GPU's memory. Model parallelism helps overcome these GPU memory limitations.
What are some limitations of training large DL models on a single GPU?

The limitations include the size of the model that can be trained due to the memory footprint scaling with the number of parameters, and reduced per-GPU batch sizes which decrease GPU utilization and training efficiency.
What does the SageMaker AI model parallel library offer?
The SageMaker AI model parallel library helps manage model parallel strategies and memory consumption, and allows efficient distributed training on multiple compute nodes.
What is the estimated GPU memory requirement per parameter for certain optimizations?
For a training job using AMP (FP16) and Adam optimizers, the required GPU memory per parameter is about 20 bytes.
Why can't some large models like GPT-3 fit in a single GPU device?
Even with top-performing GPUs, the memory required for models with hundreds of billions of parameters far exceeds what a single GPU can provide.
What are some memory-saving techniques used in model parallelism?
Memory-saving techniques include optimizer state sharding, activation checkpointing, and activation offloading.
What is sharded data parallelism?
Sharded data parallelism is a technique that splits the state of a model across GPUs within a data-parallel group to save memory during distributed training.
What does pipeline parallelism involve?
Pipeline parallelism partitions the set of layers or operations across multiple devices, maintaining each operation intact, to train large models efficiently.
How does optimizer state sharding help in training large models?
Optimizer state sharding distributes the optimizer state across data-parallel ranks to avoid redundancy, saving memory and speeding up backward propagation.
What is a receptive field in Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)?
The receptive field is defined as the region in the input space that a particular CNN's feature is looking at or is affected by.
Why is the receptive field important in CNN architectures?
All of the state-of-the-art object recognition methods design their model architectures around the receptive field concept.
What happens within a receptive field in terms of pixel importance?
Within a receptive field, the closer a pixel to the center of the field, the more it contributes to the calculation of the output feature.
What is the output feature map size if a convolution with kernel size 3x3, padding 1x1, and stride 2x2 is applied on a 5x5 input map?
The output feature map size is 3x3.
How can we calculate the number of output features in a given dimension of a CNN?
The number of output features in each dimension can be calculated using the formula explained in detail in the referenced paper.
What is the fixed-sized CNN feature map visualization?
The fixed-sized CNN visualization shows all feature maps with the same size as the input map, with features marked at the center of their receptive field.
What additional information is required to calculate the receptive field in each CNN layer?
In addition to the number of features, we need to know the receptive field size, the distance between features (jump), and the center coordinate of the first feature.
What is the information provided by the small Python program mentioned in the text?

The Python program calculates the receptive field information for all layers in a given CNN architecture and can return the size and location of a specific receptive field based on feature map and index inputs.
Which coordinate system is used for the center of the first feature in the input layer?
The coordinate system used has the center of the first feature of the input layer at 0.5.
What is the GitHub Copilot product used for?
Write better code with AI and find and fix vulnerabilities.
What is the primary purpose of GitHub Actions?
To automate any workflow.
What does Codespaces provide?
Instant dev environments.
What is bitsandbytes?
A lightweight Python wrapper around CUDA custom functions, supporting 8-bit optimizers and quantization functions.
Under what license is bitsandbytes released?
MIT license.
What hardware backends does bitsandbytes support?
Intel CPU + GPU, AMD GPU, and Apple Silicon.
What is the significance of the multi-backend alpha release of bitsandbytes?
It introduces support for AMD GPUs (ROCm) and Intel CPUs & GPUs.
Who contributed to the CPU quantization in bitsandbytes?
Fabio Cannizzo contributed with FastBinarySearch.
What is the main website for bitsandbytes documentation?
https://huggingface.co/docs/bitsandbytes/main
What is the GitHub activity statistics for bitsandbytes?
6.4k stars, 637 forks, 204 issues, 22 pull requests, 83 contributors.
What is the primary focus of the guide "Efficient Training on a Single GPU"?
The guide focuses on training large models efficiently on a single GPU.
What should you do before starting the training process detailed in the guide?
Make sure you have installed the libraries: transformers, datasets, accelerate, nvidia-ml-py3.
What is gradient accumulation used for in training models?
Gradient accumulation allows calculating gradients in smaller steps instead of the whole batch at once, enabling larger virtual batch sizes on limited GPU memory.
What does mixed precision training involve?
Mixed precision training involves using variables with lower precision (e.g., half precision) to speed up computations and reduce memory usage.
What is one potential downside of using Adafactor as an optimizer?
One downside of Adafactor is that convergence can be slower than Adam's, so experimentation is advised.
How does the 8-bit Adam optimizer reduce memory usage?
The 8-bit Adam optimizer quantizes the optimizer states to lower precision and dequantizes them for optimization, reducing memory usage while maintaining state.
What benefit does using 🤗 Accelerate provide in the training process?
🤗 Accelerate allows full control over the training loop, enabling easy scaling across different infrastructures without changing code.
How can PyTorch’s pip and conda builds be insufficient for some users?
They come prebuilt with the CUDA toolkit but might lack support for building CUDA extensions, requiring additional effort.
What is the Mixture of Experts (MoE) technique?
MoE integrates into Transformer models to increase parameters without increasing training costs by replacing FFN layers with a MoE Layer consisting of many experts.
Why might you need to scale your experiment to several GPUs?
Scaling to several GPUs might be necessary if the model does not fit onto a single GPU or for applications like pretraining large language models where speed is inadequate.
What is the name of the open source project released for benchmarking LLMs?
LLMPerf
What is the impact of 100 input tokens on latency compared to a single output token?
100 input tokens have approximately the same impact on latency as a single output token.
Which LLM API offering by Anyscale was made available in June 2024?
Anyscale Endpoints and Private Endpoints.
According to the Anyscale benchmarks, which LLM is 15% cheaper and 17% faster for typical workloads?
Anyscale Endpoints.
What is TTFT in the context of streaming applications?
TTFT is the time to first token, which indicates how long it takes before the LLM returns the first token.
Which model is mentioned as having better inter-token latency consistently?
Anyscale.
What is the difference in end-to-end latency between Anyscale and Fireworks at 5 concurrent queries?
Anyscale is 15% faster, with end-to-end latency of 4.6 seconds versus 5.3 seconds for Fireworks.
What example task was given to LLMs to produce realistic input/output token distributions in benchmarks?
Converting word representations of numerals to digital representations and selecting lines from Shakespeare’s sonnets.
What two metrics are especially important for low traffic interactive applications like chatbots?
Inter-token latency (ITL) and time to first token (TTFT).
For which use case can Fireworks be cheaper than Anyscale, according to their token pricing model?
High input to output ratio cases, such as extreme summarization (e.g., 10 input tokens to 1 output token).
What is the purpose of LLMPerf?
LLMPerf is a library for validating and benchmarking LLMs.
What are the two main tests implemented in LLMPerf for evaluating LLMs?
LLMPerf implements a load test to check for performance and a correctness test to check for correctness.
What format is used in the load test prompt?
The prompt is in the format: Randomly stream lines from the following text. Don't generate eos tokens: LINE 1, LINE 2, LINE 3, ..., with lines randomly sampled from Shakespeare sonnets.
Which tokenizer is used for counting tokens in LLMPerf?
Tokens are counted using the LlamaTokenizer regardless of which LLM API is being tested.
What does the correctness test in LLMPerf check?
The correctness test checks that the response contains the number in digit format that corresponds to a given sequence of words describing a number.
Where are the results of the load and correctness tests saved?
The results are saved in the results directory specified by the --results-dir argument, in two files: one with summary metrics and one with individual request metrics.
Which environment variables need to be set to run the vertex AI LLM compatibility test?
The following environment variables need to be set: GCLOUD_ACCESS_TOKEN, GCLOUD_PROJECT_ID, GCLOUD_REGION, VERTEXAI_ENDPOINT_ID.
How does LLMPerf test correctness using OpenAI compatible APIs?
To test correctness for OpenAI APIs, set OPENAI_API_KEY and OPENAI_API_BASE, then use the script with appropriate parameters to validate the correctness of responses converting words to numbers.
What is the command for running the most basic load test in LLMPerf?
The command is python token_benchmark_ray.py with model and various token parameters specified, among other settings.
What are the requirements for running the most basic correctness test using Anthropic API in LLMPerf?
Set ANTHROPIC_API_KEY and run the llm_correctness.py script with model, API, and test parameters as outlined.
What metric is important for applications that require high throughput?
Output tokens throughput
In what region did the LLMPerf clients run on AWS EC2?
us-west-2 (Oregon)
What is the Apache-2.0 license associated with in terms of this document?
It is the license type for the LLMPerf Leaderboard repository.
How is the output tokens throughput measured?
As the average number of output tokens returned per second.
Which model of Llama-2 chat has a median output tokens throughput of 66 in the 70B category?
meta-llama/Llama-2-70b-chat-hf
What is the P95 for the together_ai/togethercomputer/llama-2-13b-chat model in the 13B category for Time to First Token?
0.70 seconds
How many total number of requests are sent to each LLM inference provider in the benchmark?
What concurrency level is used for requests to the providers in the benchmark?
5 concurrent requests
What tested model types are included in the LLMPerf benchmarks?
7B, 13B, and 70B of LLama-2 chat models
What is Time to First Token (TTFT) especially important for?
Streaming applications, such as chatbots.
What is the Kubeflow Summit and when is it scheduled to be held?
The Kubeflow Summit is an event scheduled to be held on April 1st, 2025, in London, England.
What is Kubeflow?
Kubeflow is a community and ecosystem of open-source projects designed to address each stage in the machine learning (ML) lifecycle, making AI/ML on Kubernetes simple, portable, and scalable.
What are Standalone Kubeflow Components?
Standalone Kubeflow Components are open-source projects within the Kubeflow ecosystem that can be used independently on a Kubernetes cluster, providing flexibility for specific ML functionalities.
What is the Kubeflow Platform?
The Kubeflow Platform refers to the full suite of Kubeflow components bundled with additional integration and management tools, providing a comprehensive ML toolkit for the entire ML lifecycle.
What are the main goals of Kubeflow?

The main goals of Kubeflow include making scaling and deploying ML models simple on Kubernetes, customizing the stack based on user requirements, and providing an easy-to-use ML stack via simple manifests.
How did Kubeflow originate?
Kubeflow started as an open-source project based on how Google ran TensorFlow internally, originally designed to simplify running TensorFlow jobs on Kubernetes.
What does the Kubeflow logo represent?
The Kubeflow logo represents the letters K and F inside the heptagon of the Kubernetes logo, symbolizing the collaboration between the Kubernetes (cloud-native) and machine learning communities.
What is Kubeflow’s mission?
Kubeflow’s mission is to simplify scaling and deploying ML models to production by leveraging Kubernetes capabilities and supporting a diverse set of ML tools.
What additional components are included in the Kubeflow Platform?

The Kubeflow Platform includes additional components for interactive data exploration and model development, a central dashboard, data management, and visualization tools like PVC Viewer and TensorBoards.
How can one contribute to Kubeflow?
There are many ways to contribute to Kubeflow, including contributing to the codebase and engaging with the community. Getting started information can be found in the contributor’s guide.
When and where is the Kubeflow Summit 2025 taking place?
April 1st, 2025, in London, England.
What is Kubeflow Pipelines?
Kubeflow Pipelines is a platform for building and deploying portable, scalable machine learning (ML) workflows based on Docker containers.
What is the current released version of Kubeflow as of the latest documented release?
Kubeflow 1.9.
Which components can you use to build a pipeline in Kubeflow?
Lightweight Python Components, Containerized Python Components, Container Components, Importer Components.
What functionality does the Central Dashboard provide in Kubeflow?
The Central Dashboard provides an overview, access to profiles and namespaces, and customization options.
What are some examples of training operators available in Kubeflow?
TensorFlow Training (TFJob), PyTorch Training (PyTorchJob), PaddlePaddle Training (PaddleJob), XGBoost Training (XGBoostJob), JAX Training (JAXJob).
What is Katib used for in Kubeflow?
Katib is used for hyperparameter tuning and neural architecture search.

Distributed Training with the Training Operator.
What is the purpose of the KServe component in Kubeflow?
KServe is used for serving machine learning models.

sparkoperator.k8s.io/v1beta2.

What does ONNX stand for?
Open Neural Network Exchange
What is the primary purpose of ONNX?
ONNX is an open format built to represent machine learning models and enable interoperability between different frameworks, tools, runtimes, and compilers.
What does ONNX define as the building blocks of machine learning and deep learning models?
ONNX defines a common set of operators as the building blocks of machine learning and deep learning models.
How does ONNX contribute to interoperability in machine learning?
ONNX enables developers to use their preferred framework with a variety of inference engines without worrying about downstream inferencing implications.
What benefit does ONNX provide in terms of hardware usage?
ONNX makes it easier to access hardware optimizations by using ONNX-compatible runtimes and libraries designed to maximize performance across hardware.
How is the ONNX community characterized?
The ONNX community is active and thrives under an open governance structure that provides transparency and inclusion.
How can individuals become involved in the ONNX community?
Individuals can engage and contribute by chatting on Slack, joining a Special Interest Group (SIG), or participating in a Working Group.
What type of project is ONNX categorized under in the LF AI & Data Foundation?
ONNX is an LF AI Graduate Project.
What tools does the ONNX community provide to assist with creating and deploying deep learning models?
Frameworks & Converters, Cloud Services, Pre-Trained Models, Deploy Model Inference, Additional Tools.
Which frameworks can be used for building model frameworks & converters with ONNX?
CoreML, Optimum, Keras, NCNN, PaddlePaddle, SciKit Learn.
What cloud services can be leveraged to build, train, and infer models in the ONNX ecosystem?
Azure Cognitive Services, Azure Machine Learning.
What types of pre-trained models are available in the ONNX format?
Vision Models, Language Models.
Which tools can be used to deploy an ONNX model using runtimes designed to accelerate inferencing?
deepC, Optimum.
What additional tools are mentioned for fine-tuning ONNX models?
Tools to optimize for size, accuracy, resource utilization, and performance; and tools to visualize the computational graph.
For what purposes can you use the tool Optimum?
Build Model Frameworks & Converters and Deploy Model Inference.
What is a benefit of using pre-trained models in ONNX format?
Get started quickly with a collection of pre-trained models.
What does the ONNX additional tool "Visualize" help you understand?
It helps you better understand your model by visualizing its computational graph.
What is Name two cloud service providers mentioned for ONNX models.?
Azure Cognitive Services, Azure Machine Learning.
What is ONNX?
ONNX (Open Neural Network Exchange) is an open standard format for representing machine learning models.
What type of models are available in the ONNX Model Zoo?
The ONNX Model Zoo provides many pre-trained ONNX models for common scenarios, both validated and non-validated.
Which services can generate customized ONNX models for your data?
Azure Custom Vision Service, Azure Machine Learning Automated ML, and the Lobe desktop app can generate customized ONNX models.
How do you convert machine learning models to ONNX format?

Models can be converted to ONNX format using frameworks and tools like CoreML, Caffe, Chainer, Cognitive Toolkit, Keras, LibSVM, LightGBM, MATLAB, ML.NET, MXNet, PyTorch, SciKit-Learn, SINGA, TensorFlow, and others.
What tools can be used to score ONNX models?
ONNX models can be scored using Caffe2, Cognitive Toolkit, CoreML, MATLAB, Menoh, ML.NET, MXNet, ONNX Runtime, SINGA, TensorFlow, TensorRT, Windows ML, and Vespa.ai.
What are some tools for visualizing ONNX models?
ONNX models can be visualized using Netdrawer, Netron, and Zetane, which offer different ways to visualize models and internal tensors.
What is the aim of the ONNX tutorials section?
The ONNX tutorials demonstrate how to use ONNX in practice for varied scenarios across frameworks, platforms, and device types.
What can the ONNX Runtime be used for?
The ONNX Runtime can be used for real-time ONNX inference and provides tutorials for deploying ONNX models on different devices and platforms.
How can ONNX models be enhanced or customized?
ONNX models can be enhanced or customized using custom operators, which allow for the exporting of PyTorch models with custom operations to ONNX.
How can you contribute to ONNX?
Contributions to ONNX can include improvements to converter tools, new ONNX bindings, and submitting tutorials by making a pull request to the repository.
What is the purpose of the ONNX Model Zoo?
To provide a collection of pre-trained, state-of-the-art models in the ONNX format that developers, researchers, and enthusiasts can use.
Which types of models are included in the ONNX Model Zoo?
Computer Vision, Natural Language Processing (NLP), Generative AI, Graph Machine Learning, and other models.
What is the ONNX format used for?
It is an open standard format used to represent machine learning models.
What is Git LFS used for in the ONNX Model Zoo?
Git LFS is used to handle large files such as ONNX model files.
What is Dynamic and Static Quantization implemented by Intel Neural Compressor?
It is a method to quickly find the best quantized model using different quantization techniques for ONNX models.

Faster-RCNN

ONNX Runtime is a cross-platform, high performance machine-learning inferencing and training accelerator.
Which machine learning frameworks does ONNX Runtime support?
ONNX Runtime supports models from deep learning frameworks such as PyTorch and TensorFlow/Keras, as well as classical machine learning libraries such as scikit-learn, LightGBM, and XGBoost.
How does ONNX Runtime provide optimal performance?
ONNX Runtime provides optimal performance by leveraging hardware accelerators where applicable, alongside graph optimizations and transforms.
What is the benefit of using ONNX Runtime for training on NVIDIA GPUs?
ONNX Runtime training can accelerate model training time on multi-node NVIDIA GPUs with a one-line addition to existing PyTorch training scripts.

ONNX Runtime welcomes contributions and feedback, and they recommend checking out the contribution guidelines and filing a GitHub Issue for feature requests or bug reports.

What is the purpose of TensorFlow Model Garden?
The purpose is to help TensorFlow users take full advantage of TensorFlow for research and product development and to improve transparency and reproducibility.
What are the types of models available in TensorFlow Model Garden?

What is the official directory in TensorFlow Model Garden?

How can you install TensorFlow Model Garden?

What package should you install for nightly updates?

How do you add the models directory to the Python path?

What is Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG)?

Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) is a sophisticated approach that enhances the capabilities of large language models (LLMs) by integrating retrieval mechanisms with generative models. This synergy allows the model to access a wealth of external knowledge, significantly improving the relevance and accuracy of generated responses.
What is the core mechanism of Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG)?

The core of RAG lies in its retrieval mechanism, which operates by embedding both documents and queries in a shared latent space. When a user poses a question, the system retrieves the most pertinent document chunk, which is then fed into the generative model.
What are the benefits of Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG)?

RAG enables LLMs to tap into a vast array of documents, ensuring that responses are grounded in factual information. It offers cost-effectiveness by leveraging existing documents, and versatility in output by generating diverse formats of text including code snippets, creative writing, and structured data.
How does RAG differ from Semantic Search?

While both RAG and semantic search aim to improve information retrieval, RAG specifically focuses on augmenting the generative capabilities of LLMs by using retrieved information to enhance the generation process. In contrast, semantic search retrieves relevant documents based on meaning.
What are some practical applications of RAG?

RAG is successfully implemented in numerous real-world scenarios including customer support, content creation, and data analysis. It provides accurate answers in customer support, assists in generating ideas or drafts for content creation, and enhances data analysis through generating insights from documents.
What strategies can optimize the effectiveness of RAG?

To maximize RAG effectiveness, it is essential to optimize both the retrieval and generative components. Strategies include tuning retrieval parameters to ensure relevant results and improving prompt engineering to guide the LLM in utilizing the retrieved context effectively.
How does RAG enhance question-answering systems?

RAG improves question-answering systems by leveraging external knowledge bases, ensuring that responses are grounded in verified information and are contextually relevant. This technique minimizes the chances of generating incorrect or misleading information.
What is the significance of integrating RAG with vector databases?

The integration of RAG with vector databases enhances its performance in real-time applications by facilitating efficient retrieval of relevant documents, crucial for applications requiring immediate responses. It ensures scalability and maintains performance without compromising accuracy.
In what formats can RAG generate creative content?

RAG can generate diverse formats of creative content including poems, scripts, emails, and more, by grounding its outputs in external knowledge, thereby producing high-quality and factually credible text.
Why is RAG considered a cost-effective approach?

RAG is more cost-effective than traditional fine-tuning methods, as it does not require extensive labeled datasets or extra computational resources since it leverages existing documents for improving response accuracy and relevance.
What does BM stand for in Okapi BM25?
BM stands for "best matching".
Who were the developers of the probabilistic retrieval framework that BM25 is based on?
Stephen E. Robertson, Karen Spärck Jones, and others developed the probabilistic retrieval framework.
What does BM25 stand for?
BM25 stands for Best Matching 25.
What university was the Okapi information retrieval system implemented at?
The Okapi information retrieval system was implemented at London's City University.
What are the typical ranges for the k1 parameter in BM25?
The k1 parameter usually ranges from 1.2 to 2.0.
What is the default value for the b parameter in BM25?
The default value for b is 0.75.
In information theory, what is the information content of the message "D contains q"?
The information content is log(N/n(q)), where N is the total number of documents and n(q) is the number of documents containing q.
What happens to BM25 at the extreme values of coefficient b?
BM25 turns into BM11 for b=1 and BM15 for b=0.
What is BM25F?
BM25F is a variant of BM25 which considers the document as composed of several fields with different importance, term relevance saturation, and length normalization.
How does BM25+ address a deficiency of the standard BM25?
BM25+ addresses the deficiency where long documents that match the query term are scored unfairly by adding a parameter δ to ensure proper term frequency normalization by document length.

What is ExecuTorch?
ExecuTorch is an end-to-end solution for enabling on-device inference capabilities across mobile and edge devices.
What can you learn about in the PyTorch Blogs & News section?

What is the focus of the PyTorch Foundation?
Learn more about the PyTorch Foundation Governing Board and how you can become a member.
What events and platforms can you use to stay updated about PyTorch?
Find events, webinars, and podcasts to stay updated about PyTorch.

GitHub Copilot is an AI tool that helps developers write better code.
What is the purpose of GitHub Actions?
GitHub Actions is used to automate workflows.
What are GitHub Codespaces?
GitHub Codespaces provide instant development environments.
How can GitHub help manage code changes?
GitHub offers a Code Review feature to manage code changes.
What does the GitHub Code Search feature allow you to do?
GitHub Code Search allows you to find more with less searching.
What industries does GitHub provide solutions for?
GitHub provides solutions for industries such as Healthcare, Financial services, Manufacturing, and Government.
What is the GitHub Enterprise platform?
The GitHub Enterprise platform is an AI-powered developer platform with enterprise-grade features.

GitHub Learning Pathways include white papers, eBooks, and webinars as learning resources.
How does GitHub support open source developers?
GitHub supports open source developers through GitHub Sponsors.
What type of support does GitHub Premium Support offer?

How many boxes are there in the Open Images Dataset V7?
How many classes are present in the dataset for bounding boxes?
What is the total number of instance segmentations available?
How many classes are there in the instance segmentations?
How many relationship annotations are recorded in the dataset?
What is the number of unique relationships annotated?
How many localized narratives are included in the dataset?
What is the total number of point-level annotations?
How many classes are there in point-level annotations?
What is the count of image-level labels present?
What is the primary goal of the challenge?
To recognize objects from a number of visual object classes in realistic scenes using a supervised learning approach.
How many object classes are selected for recognition in the challenge?
Twenty object classes have been selected for recognition.
What are the two main types of competitions in the challenge?
There are two main competitions and two smaller scale "taster" competitions.
How does the VOC2007 challenge differ from the VOC2006 challenge?
The number of classes increased from 10 to 20, and taster challenges for segmentation and layout were added.
What information does each image in the training set contain?
Each image has an annotation file giving bounding boxes and object class labels for each object present in one of the twenty classes.
What is the purpose of the validation set in the provided data?
To demonstrate how the evaluation software works ahead of the competition submission.
What are participants required to do with their results from the competition?
Participants are required to submit a single set of results per method employed and provide contact details, a list of contributors, and a brief description of the method used.
Who should receive queries about the use or ownership of the data?
Queries should be addressed to the organizers, specifically Mark Everingham at me@comp.leeds.ac.uk.
What is the intended use of the development kit for participants?
Participants can use the development kit to store results and generate archives suitable for submission.
Who acknowledged assistance in annotation for the VOC2007 database?
Acknowledgements include Moray Allan, Patrick Buehler, Terry Herbert, Anitha Kannan, Julia Lasserre, Alain Lehmann, Mukta Prasad, Till Quack, John Quinn, and Florian Schroff.
What content can you find in the PyTorch documentation?
Comprehensive guidance on how to use PyTorch and information on domain-specific libraries.
What is PyTorch Edge?
A platform for building innovative and privacy-aware AI experiences for edge devices.
What is ExecuTorch?
An end-to-end solution for enabling on-device inference capabilities across mobile and edge devices.
What resources can you find in the PyTorch community?
Tools to contribute, learn, and discuss PyTorch code, issues, and research.
What is the PyTorch Forum?
A place to discuss PyTorch code, issues, installation, and research.
What type of content is in the PyTorch Blog?
The latest technical news and happenings about PyTorch.
What does the PyTorch Ecosystem offer?
Tools and frameworks that extend PyTorch capabilities.
What is the main purpose of PyTorch Recipes?
To provide bite-size, ready-to-deploy PyTorch code examples.
What is the PyTorch Foundation?
A governing board that supports the PyTorch open source project.
What is covered in the Intro to PyTorch - YouTube Series?
The series helps master PyTorch basics with engaging tutorials.
What is transfer learning in the context of Convolutional Networks?
Transfer learning involves using a ConvNet pretrained on a large dataset as an initialization or a fixed feature extractor for a task of interest, rather than training a ConvNet from scratch.
Why is training an entire Convolutional Network from scratch rare?
It is rare to have a dataset of sufficient size to train a Convolutional Network from scratch, so pretraining on a large dataset like ImageNet is more common.
What is one common usage of a ConvNet in transfer learning?
A ConvNet can be used as a fixed feature extractor by removing the last fully-connected layer and treating the rest of the ConvNet to extract features for a new task.
What are CNN codes?
CNN codes are the activations of the hidden layer immediately before the classifier in a network like AlexNet, resulting in a 4096-D vector for each image.
Why is it important for CNN codes to be ReLUd?
ReLUing the codes ensures they are thresholded at zero, which is important for performance if the codes were thresholded during the ConvNet training.
What is the benefit of fine-tuning a pretrained ConvNet?
Fine-tuning allows for updating the weights of a pretrained network, either all layers or just the higher-level ones, to better fit the new dataset.
In which scenario might it be beneficial to train a linear classifier on the CNN codes?
When the new dataset is small and similar to the original dataset, using a linear classifier on the CNN codes could be most beneficial to avoid overfitting.
How can pretrained models constrain further architecture modifications?
Using a pretrained network may limit changes, such as removing layers, but modifications like changing input image sizes remain possible due to parameter sharing.
What should be considered when setting learning rates for fine-tuning a pre-trained ConvNet?

Typically, a smaller learning rate should be used for fine-tuning ConvNet weights to prevent large distortions, while a larger rate can be used for randomly-initialized weights in the new linear classifier.
What is the impact of dataset size and similarity on transfer learning strategies?

The decision on whether to retrain or fine-tune depends on the dataset size and its similarity to the original dataset; this affects how many layers might be retrained and whether to use pretrained weights.
